spanishExample: Sabes que él no lo puede saber a menos que ella lo sepa.
englishTranslation: You know he can’t know it unless she knows it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Sabían *to cook.*
englishTranslation: They knew how to cook.

spanishExample: Sabías menos de lo que yo sabía.
englishTranslation: You knew less than I knew.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
de used to mean “than” in numerical comparisons

spanishExample: Sabrá lo que ellos saben ahora.
englishTranslation: She will know what they know now.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
sabrá: "will know", "he/she/it will know" (Saber, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Sabrán esto cuando yo se lo quiera *to tell.*
englishTranslation: They will know this when I want to tell them it.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
sabrán: "will know", "they will know" (Saber, future, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Sabrás cuál es la idea en una hora.
englishTranslation: You will know what the idea is in an hour.
vocabIncluded: sabrás: "will know", "you will know" (Saber, future, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Sabrías todo esto si hicieras el trabajo.
englishTranslation: You would know all of this if you did the work.
vocabIncluded: sabrías: "would know", "you would know" (Saber, conditional, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Sé lo que sabes.
englishTranslation: I know what you know.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: Sé que ella no sabía, pero no hubo un problema.
englishTranslation: I know she didn’t know, but there wasn’t a problem.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Si él supiera lo que ella sabía, no irían.
englishTranslation: If he knew what she knew, they wouldn’t go.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
irían: "would go", "they would go" (Ir, conditional, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Si hubiera un problema, ellos lo sabrían.
englishTranslation: If there was a problem, they would know it.
vocabIncluded: hubiera: "there were to be" (Haber, past subjunctive, impersonal)
sabrían: "would know", "they would know" (Saber, conditional, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Si hubiera una fiesta, él sabría *to dance.*
englishTranslation: If there were a party, he would know how to dance.
vocabIncluded: hubiera: "there were to be" (Haber, past subjunctive, impersonal)
sabría: "would know", "he/she/it would know" (Saber, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si me lo *you told,* lo sabría.
englishTranslation: If you told me it, I would know it.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
sabría: "would know", "I would know" (Saber, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si supiera lo que ella te *told,* estaría *mad.*
englishTranslation: If he knew what she told you, he would be mad.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
estaría: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Si supieran qué forma hacer, no sería un problema.
englishTranslation: If they knew what shape to make, it wouldn’t be a problem.
vocabIncluded: "qué" in an implied question, not an actual question
sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)
supieran: "knew", "they knew" (Saber, past subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Si supieras lo que él sabe, no estarías aquí.
englishTranslation: If you knew what he knows, you wouldn’t be here.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
estarías: "would be", "you would be" (Estar, conditional, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Si supieras lo que yo sabía…
englishTranslation: If you knew what I knew…
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: Si yo supiera lo que estas personas saben, sería mejor.
englishTranslation: If I knew what these people know, it would be better.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Supe que ese no era el mejor lado ese día.
englishTranslation: I knew that that wasn’t the best side that day.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supe: "knew / found out", "I knew / found out" (Saber, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Supe su nombre en ese momento.
englishTranslation: I found out his name at that moment.
vocabIncluded: supe: "knew / found out", "I knew / found out" (Saber, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Supo que no sabíamos.
englishTranslation: He found out that we didn’t know.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supe: "knew / found out", "he/she/it knew / found out" (Saber, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Tienes que saber que él supo la verdad ese día.
englishTranslation: You have to know that he found out the truth that day.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supe: "knew / found out", "he/she/it knew / found out" (Saber, preterite, 3rd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Al menos están vivos.
englishTranslation: At least they are alive.

spanishExample: Cuando lo sepa, estará feliz.
englishTranslation: When she knows it, she will be happy.
vocabIncluded: estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Cuando sepas la verdad, todo estará bien.
englishTranslation: When you know the truth, everything will be fine.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Ella quiere que sepamos que él es la única persona que puede hacerlo.
englishTranslation: She wants us to know he is the only person that can do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Ella sabrá la historia cuando yo la sepa.
englishTranslation: She will know the story when I know it.
vocabIncluded: sabrá: "will know", "he/she/it will know" (Saber, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Ella sabría si solo hubiera un poco.
englishTranslation: She would know if there were only a little.
vocabIncluded: hubiera: "there were to be" (Haber, past subjunctive, impersonal)
sabría: "would know", "he/she/it would know" (Saber, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Es cierto que esta fiesta es viva.
englishTranslation: It’s certain that this party is lively.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
cierto: "certain", used with Ser to express certainty (adjective)
vivo: "lively" for events/objects (adjective typically used with Ser)

spanishExample: Ese día sabrás lo que yo sé.
englishTranslation: That day you will know what I know.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
sabrás: "will know", "you will know" (Saber, future, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Había una persona aquí esta mañana.
englishTranslation: There was a person here this morning.
vocabIncluded: había: "there was/were" indicating existence (Haber, imperfect, impersonal)

spanishExample: Hubo un tipo de *cake* en la fiesta.
englishTranslation: There was a type of cake at the party.

spanishExample: *I hope* que haya una casa ahí.
englishTranslation: I hope there is a house there.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: *I hope* que no haya problemas.
englishTranslation: I hope there isn’t trouble.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *I hope* que sepan que lo sabrán cuando *they study.*
englishTranslation: I hope they know that they will know it when they study.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sabrán: "will know", "they will know" (Saber, future, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: *I’m so sorry,* no lo sabíamos.
englishTranslation: I’m so sorry, we didn’t know it.

spanishExample: Lo he sabido por mucho tiempo.
englishTranslation: I have known it for a long time.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Lo hice para que él lo sepa.
englishTranslation: I did it so that he would know it.

spanishExample: Lo sabe y yo lo sabré también.
englishTranslation: He knows it and I will know it too.
vocabIncluded: sabré: "will know", "I will know" (Saber, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Lo sabré cuando ellos lo sepan.
englishTranslation: I will know it when they know it.
vocabIncluded: sabré: "will know", "I will know" (Saber, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Lo sabremos cuando yo lo sepa.
englishTranslation: We’ll know it when I know it.
vocabIncluded: sabremos: "will know", "we will know" (Saber, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No lo sabría.
englishTranslation: I wouldn’t know it.
vocabIncluded: sabría: "would know", "I would know" (Saber, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: No sabemos lo que ellos sabían.
englishTranslation: We don’t know what they knew.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: No sabríamos todo lo que has sabido.
englishTranslation: We wouldn’t know everything you have known.
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)
sabríamos: "would know", "we would know" (Saber, conditional, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Quiero que sepas que esto es lo mejor.
englishTranslation: I want you to know this is the best.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Sabemos que no lo sabías.
englishTranslation: We know that you didn’t know it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Sabes muy poco de esto.
englishTranslation: You know very little of this.
